title: Fixes cargo deny and update dependencies
body: This updates a bunch of dependencies that were causing cargo deny issues and other compilation problems. Please note that I still had to ignore the omnipresent `time` and `chrono` RUSTSEC advisories as `openid` has not updated. I plan on submitting a PR to use the `time` crate instead over there to fix the issue and then those could be removed. However, I did address all other direct and transitive imports of `chrono`

title: Adds codeowners
body: This will make it so we get auto assigned on reviews so we don't miss them among our other notifications (like I did 🤦 ). @technosophos and @bacongobbler I added both of you. If there are others who we need to add, please do so!

title: feat(cli): only use ansi logging on tty
fix(server): move /v1/healthz to /healthz
fix(Makefile): add default value for BINDLE_DIRECTORY var
body:
I was following the steps in the README around [starting the server](https://github.com/deislabs/bindle#starting-the-server), specifically:

`If you would like to run the server with cargo run (useful when debugging), use make serve or make serve-tls. (The first time you run make serve-tls, it will prompt you to create a testing TLS cert.)`

When I ran `make serve`, I encountered the following error:

```
$ make serve
cargo run --features cli --bin bindle-server -- --directory  --address 127.0.0.1:8080   --unauthenticated
    Finished dev [unoptimized + debuginfo] target(s) in 0.52s
     Running `target/debug/bindle-server --directory --address '127.0.0.1:8080' --unauthenticated`
error: The argument '--directory <bindle_directory>' requires a value but none was supplied
```

Therefore, this PR proposes to add a default value in the Makefile for the BUNDLE_DIRECTORY var used in the command above (but currently empty due to no default being present).  Not sure the best value for the job; currently have it at `${HOME}/.bindle/bindles`, as this is a sample location mentioned in the [docs](https://github.com/deislabs/bindle/blob/main/docs/README.md#using-bindle).

Alternatively, we could update the referenced docs above to make it known that the user must set a value for this var before running the make target.

title: Updated versions to 0.6.0
body: Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: feat(client): add json output to bindle info
body: Closes: #234

title: fix(Makefile): default to unauthenticated in Makefile
A missive from Noki, god of nits
body: ⚡ LET ⚡ LESS ⚡ NIT! ⚡

title: Refactor merging config with cli options
Add unauthenticated flag to bindle-server
body:
Makes running bindle-server without authentication an explicit option.

Closes: #235

title: Upgrade deps with `cargo upgrade`.
body:
This commit upgrades bindle's deps with `cargo upgrade`.

For almost all the deps, this just sets the patch version to the latest available, thus treating it as the minimum patch level for the given major.minor.

This specifically upgrades the `semver` crate to latest, as bindle was using a very old version that prevents downstream crates from using a newer version. As a result, a code change was required to maintain "npm" compatibility (which is no longer a thing in the `semver` crate).

The `dirs` create is upgraded to `4.0` with this change (API compatible).

The `rand` dependency was not updated as an upstream dependency uses a
backwards incompatible version.

title: Don't require a value passed for the --use-embedded-db
improve error messages for network connection failures
body:
This traps networking errors and makes a noble effort to be informative.

Most, if not all, network errors will be due to either network failure or pointing at the wrong URL. This PR tries to catch those that result in hitting the wrong URL.

Server responds 400 BAD REQUEST:

```
$ bindle --server http://bindle.f1sh.ca:8080/v1 search
Server has encountered an error: The request could not be handled by the server. Verify your Bindle server URL
```

A networking error occurred during connection (e.g. wrong port, server disconnects abruptly):

```
$ bindle --server http://bindle.f1sh.ca/v1 search
Server has encountered an error: Protocol error. Verify the Bindle URL
```


Closes #231 

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: Clearer error on bad token file
body:
Previously if you had a bad token file (like, one left over from a previous go at Bindle auth) it gave you

```
Invalid TOML

Error trace:
        1: expected an equals, found eof at line 1 column 41
```

which didn't help you resolve it.

With this change it gives you:

```
Invalid configuration: Error loading token file "/home/ivan/.config/bindle/.token": Invalid TOML
```

which is hopefully enough to track down the problem and decide what you want to do about it.

Fixes #228.

title: Respect config file values
body:
Make `use_db_embedded` field optional to prevent toml parsing errors
when not set.

Closes: #212

title: chore(*): Bumps bindle version
feat(server): Adds anonymous auth support for get endpoints
body:
The major change here is that now if no authorization header is passed
authentication will be "successful" and pass on anonymous auth instead.

title: feat(server): add health check endpoint to api
feat(*): Adds OIDC login functionality to the server and the client
body:
Authentication is now done using OIDC and JWT verification for completely
stateless auth. This is a major feature add with several breaking changes.
In particular, to construct a client you now need a `TokenManager` to
properly provide a token (if any) to your requests. This ended being much
cleaner than handling several different options

Note, there are probably various refactors that could be done here and those
are noted with TODOs. Most of them are things that could change anyway as
we add further authn/z features.

To test this feature, all you need is the client ID for any OIDC compatible
provider. For example, there is a common one for using Microsoft accounts
for anyone with a public Microsoft account. You can also create your own
Oauth application in something like AAD.

title: Box Warp filters to speed up build time
body: This boxes the warp filters so that the compile-time checks do not take 5-15 minutes.

title: add HTTP Basic Auth to the client and the server
body:
This adds support for HTTP Basic Auth. Per the docs/README.md:

To use HTTP Basic authentication, you must generate an `htpasswd` file using Bcrypt:

```console
$ htpasswd -Bc htpasswd admin
New password: 
Re-type new password: 
Adding password for user admin
```

(The `htpasswd` program comes on many Linux/Unix distros. Officially it is part of the Apache Web Server project.)

Then you need to supply the `--htpasswd-file` option at `bindle-server` startup:

```console
$ bindle-server --htpasswd-file test/data/htpasswd
```

> Currently, only bcrypt is supported in htpasswd files. At the time of this writing, bcrypt is the most secure algorithm supported by htpasswd.

Closes #217

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: add --format to search
body:
Add support for `-f`|`--format`. (Note that I didn't use `-o`|`--output` because we have already used it as a flag for output files)

The new formatter gives users the choice between `table` (new default), `toml`, and `json`. It is easy enough to add other serializers.

New default output:

```console
$ bindle search -q example
example.com/hello/1.0.0:        Autogenerated example bindle for Wagi
example.com/hello/1.1.0:        Autogenerated example bindle for Wagi
example.com/hello/1.2.0:        Autogenerated example bindle for Wagi
example.com/hello/1.3.0:        Autogenerated example bindle for Wagi
example.com/hello/1.3.1:        Autogenerated example bindle for Wagi
example.com/hello/1.3.2:        Autogenerated example bindle for Wagi
example.com/hello/1.3.3:        Autogenerated example bindle for Wagi
example.com/hello/1.4.0:        Autogenerated example bindle for Wagi
=== Showing results 1 to 8 of 8 (limit: 50)
```

In case the results are beyond the limit:

```console
$ bindle search -q example -f table --limit 5
example.com/hello/1.0.0:        Autogenerated example bindle for Wagi
example.com/hello/1.1.0:        Autogenerated example bindle for Wagi
example.com/hello/1.2.0:        Autogenerated example bindle for Wagi
example.com/hello/1.3.0:        Autogenerated example bindle for Wagi
example.com/hello/1.3.1:        Autogenerated example bindle for Wagi
=== Showing results 1 to 5 of 8 (limit: 5) - More results are available with --offset=8
```

And new JSON support:

```console
bindle search -q example -f json --limit 1
{
  "query": "example",
  "strict": true,
  "offset": 0,
  "limit": 1,
  "total": 8,
  "more": true,
  "yanked": false,
  "invoices": [
    {
      "bindleVersion": "1.0.0",
      "yanked": null,
      "yankedSignature": null,
      "bindle": {
        "name": "example.com/hello",
        "version": "1.0.0",
        "description": "Autogenerated example bindle for Wagi",
        "authors": null
      },
      "annotations": null,
      "parcel": [
        {
          "label": {
            "sha256": "1f2bc60e4e39297d9a3fd06b789f6f00fac4272d72da6bf5dae20fb5f32d45a4",
            "mediaType": "application/wasm",
            "name": "examples/hello.wasm",
            "size": 165,
            "annotations": null,
            "feature": {
              "wagi": {
                "route": "/"
              }
            },
            "origin": null
          },
          "conditions": null
        }
      ],
      "group": null,
      "signature": null
    }
  ]
}%    
```


BREAKING: TOML support now requiers the `--format toml` arg.

Closes #208

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: Generated key-file.toml should have RW perms
body:
Fixes #192 

Generate key file permissions switched from 0o700 (RWX) to 0o600 (RW).

Signed-off-by: Nitish Malhotra <nitish.malhotra@gmail.com>

title: Super nit, possibly incorrect but what the heck?
feat(server): Adds Github authentication support to the server
body:
So this is a bit gnarly here, but functional. Basically, the login flow goes like this:

Client calls `/login` endpoint with their desired provider -> bindle server starts device code flow ->
bindle server returns auth code details to client -> client calls proper endpoint to retrieve token

On every API call, the passed token will be validated against the auth provider. We will likely
want to optimize this with some sort of cache in the future. Ideally, we can add other providers
in the future using OIDC.

Closes #209

title: fix(ci): Updates references from master
body:
We forgot to change the build pipeline to look for main instead of master
so canary releases haven't been building

title: Provide better errors for non-GET operations
body:
All 404s were getting interpreted as missing index/parcel. Turns out some 404s occur because the endpoint is missing. So this at least tries to distinguish between the two situations.

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: fix(*): Fixes flaky windows test
body: After doing some digging, it looks like `flush`ing the file after write solves the problem. My theory, which I cannot entire prove, is that because the CLI stops execution, the file write did not complete, particularly on slower systems like the GH Action runners. So now we make sure to manually flush the file in places where we are not using the `write` style helper functions. I fixed this anywhere in the CLI it was not flushing. I also noticed that the logic as specified in the `create-key` command would not work with the current `save_file` method as it was using `create_new` to save the file. This changes it to `create` so that it can overwrite the existing file

title: exp(provider): Adds support for experimental embedded provider
body:
This PR adds support for a new embedded `Provider` backed by the `sled`
embedded database and with more efficient data encoding. This new
provider is behind a feature flag and is not compiled into `bindle-server`
by default. Tests have also been updated to check both providers, but
the client tests still only test with the `FileProvider`.

The motivation behind this is that the file system provider requires a bunch of
bespoke logic to check things like locking and various OS specific things. We
also have to front everything with an in-memory LRU cache. Tools like `sled`
already have most of these features built in, plus additional guarantees from
being a database (such as atomic transations and upsert commands). This also
uses a binary encoding format to store the data using less bytes and to
decrease serialization and deserialization time. All of these reasons
sounded like pretty good justification for giving it a whirl. Use of bindle
can continue as before until we decide whether we like this or not as it
is all behind a feature flag.

Any comments on open TODOs are welcome!

title: default http2_prior_knowledge to false
body:
fixes #202

Before:

```
><> bindle --server https://bindle.f1sh.ca:8080/v1 search
Error creating request

Error trace:
	1: error sending request for url (https://bindle.f1sh.ca:8080/v1/_q): http2 error: protocol error: frame with invalid size
	2: http2 error: protocol error: frame with invalid size
	3: protocol error: frame with invalid size
```

After:

```
><> bindle --server https://bindle.f1sh.ca:8080/v1 search
query = ""
strict = true
offset = 0
limit = 50
total = 0
more = false
yanked = false
invoices = []
```

title: fix(tests): Attempts to fix macos flake
body:
I believe that the slowness of the GH runners was creating issues when using
`cargo run` to run the server binary - even after previously building it. This
changes things to run the built binary directly instead, avoid the overhead of
"rebuilding" it. It also makes things more generic so people consuming test
utils are not required to have a specific binary name

title: add print-key command
body:
This prints the public key entry for a private key in a bindle client's `secrets_keys.toml` or a bindle server's `signing-keys.toml` file.

Example:

```console
$ bindle print-key
version = "1.0"

[[key]]
label = "Matt <example@example.com>"
roles = ["creator"]
key = "Qx6Q8d0K8sb0828S8hivB9ev+CWB+i1jqv596F3MbFQ="
labelSignature = "v6trXDbBKLl+9dXgmNlySajcPYHTeqwPy3Zy+PybD5qKGfPoMhkEp1pnkpSWHz5KT1F5yGxyUAvk4EbFmW7KDg=="
```

Note that you can use `--label` to filter to only keys whose label matches. This is approximately consistent with the way GPG works.


```console
$ bindle print-key --label Matt
version = "1.0"

[[key]]
label = "Matt <example@example.com>"
roles = ["creator"]
key = "Qx6Q8d0K8sb0828S8hivB9ev+CWB+i1jqv596F3MbFQ="
labelSignature = "v6trXDbBKLl+9dXgmNlySajcPYHTeqwPy3Zy+PybD5qKGfPoMhkEp1pnkpSWHz5KT1F5yGxyUAvk4EbFmW7KDg=="
```

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: Make client use same env var as server
body:
Change BINDLE_DIR to BINDLE_DIRECTORY in the client options to match the server options.

Closes #181

title: ref(server): Handles IO errors more gracefully

There were places we were returning the IO errors from server startup without
adding any context. This maps those errors to more useful messages in case
of a failure.

Closes #185

title: feat(server): Improves errors returned from proxies and signature issues
body:
Our current implementation just to_string'd things for nested errors. This
led to very confusing errors for the user. Now this un-nests stuff to get a
a better message to the user for client errors

Before:

```
Invalid request (status code 400): Some("failed signature check invoice")
```

After:

```
Invalid request (status code 400): Some("no suitable key for signing data")
```

Closes #193

title: Spec: describe annotations and reserved annotations
body:
This describes label annotations, defines two reserved annotations, and clarifies invoice annotations.

Closes #182 

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: feat(*): Adds `cargo deny` to build pipeline
body:
This adds package auditing and `cargo deny` to the build workflow for
bindle. This should inform us if we are using any projects with security
advisories or ones we have explicitly denied (none right now). This will
also run a license check to make sure we are at least using licensed
projects. It can be tweaked to allow specific licenses in the future.

As part of this, I have addressed any changes it found

title: fix(*): Marks `Signed` trait as `Sealed`
body:
Somehow we missed this in the review so technically the trait was wide
open. This seals the trait and bumps the version in one go and then I'll
yank 0.4.0

title: chore(*): Bumps bindle version
fix(signature): Ensures that a saved key has 0700 bits on unix
body: Closes #115

title: fix(file): Ensures that windows part file actually locks
body:
Based on the documentation for the windows specific code, it looks like
the share mode is set to allow other processes to read/write/delete the
file. This removes those permissions so that it should stop a new file
from being simultaneously created.

Closes #173

title: feat(*): Adds new Verified and Signed traits
body:
This changes how the providers work by only taking invoices that have
been verified and signed. This is accomplished using a sealed trait
so that signing must be done by library code. The big change is that
providers no longer have to implement signing.

This work supersedes (and contains the commits from, for history sake,
PR #168)

Closes #141

title: Rename BINDLE_SERVER_URL to BINDLE_URL
body:
See https://github.com/deislabs/hippofactory/issues/25 for discussion

Closes #170

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: use MIME library for parsing headers
body:
This switches the `Accept` header parsing to use more of the `mime` library. However, since that library doesn't have support for `application/toml`, at the end of the day it is still about 80% string manipulation. For consistency, I have left the JSON handling as-is, too.

Closes #154

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: added accessor methods for StandaloneRead
body:
When pairing with @adamreese on https://github.com/deislabs/wagi/issues/79, I noticed that we had some missing features on `StandaloneRead`. This adds accessors to the invoice and parcels so that client users do not have to know anything about the file structure of a standalone bindle.

Also refactored the `Makefile` because I am impatient and want to run tests faster.

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: feat(server): Adds configurable verification strategy
body:
You are now able to specify the verification strategy with a command line
flag or an item in the config file. This ended up being a bit more involved
than we initially thought due to the need to implement a custom deserialize
for the strategy

Closes #143

title: SSL/TLS configuration streamlining
body:
This streamlines the TLS configuration and matches it to a similar PR for Wagi.

- `make serve-tls` runs the server with TLS
- `make gen-cert` generates a testing TLS certificate
- The CLI args and env vars are changed to match Wagi's
- Other CLI help text was cleaned up to clarify the difference between TLS keys and signing keys
- The docs are updated

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: feat(verification): Updates with new verification strategy
body:
As I started to work on #143, I realized that we technically have 2 Mulitple Attestation
strategies that would be better to explicitly document and define rather than having
that behavior defined by a boolean flag. This also has the side effect of making parsing a config
object and command line flag easier to implement for #143

title: docs(README): Updates the Using Bindle section to reflect reality
Reworked error output for ID and SemVer parse errors
body:
This results in error output that walks the nested errors and prints the root cause:

```console
$ bindle --server $BINDLE_HOST push foo
Error: Invalid id: InvalidId("foo")

Caused by:
    Invalid bindle ID foo. A bindle ID should be NAME/VERSION

$ bindle --server $BINDLE_HOST push foo/bar/dadsfas
Error: Invalid id: InvalidSemver("dadsfas")

Caused by:
    ID does not contain a valid semantic version (e.g. 1.2.3): dadsfas
```

Closes #159

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: The Clone Wars: Attack on the Clones
body: This PR consists of several mostly atomic commits that do some cleanup and small refactors that were much needed (it has been a while since we last cleaned up the code). Each commit explains specifically what was done and why, so I would recommend reviewing each commit separately when reviewing.

title: Allow consumers to set "insecure" mode
body: Provide an option for consumers of the Bindle client crate to support "invalid" (typically self-signed) certificates.  E.g. hippofactory could add a `-k` option so it could push to a dev Bindle server or avoid Let's Encrypt Ubuntu woes.

title: fix(provider/file): Uses partfile for invoice and improves locking
body:
This has some small improvements to the new `PartFile` to make sure that it
takes a file "lock" right when it is created. It also refactored the `create_invoice`
method to use the new `PartFile`. I also added a test to at least give
us a sanity check that a double write doesn't cause an issue

title: fix(server): Allows for proper parsing of charset
body: Closes #131

title: doc(spec): Better documents the missing parcels body
body: Closes #114

title: fix(*): Uses XDG based locations as defaults for data storage
body:
Both of these issues were similar and small enough to fit into one PR.

Closes #123
Closes #121

title: feat(server): Adds check against parcel length before saving
body: This partially implements #148. I wasn't sure whether we should handle this on the client side or not. See the issue for more discussion on this point.

title: removed the concept of empty groups from spec
body:
Per a long discussion with @itowlson, we have decided that a parcel that is a member of no groups is a non-feature. It means that there are parcels that must be present on the server, but which are never pulled. At best, it is a way of hiding data that a user could be directed to pull directly (via `curl`, for example). At worst, we made it really easy to hide nefarious stuff on a Bindle server.

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: Option to negotiate HTTP/2 instead of assuming
body:
By default, the Bindle client goes straight to HTTP/2 when talking to a Bindle server.  This is usually safe because the Bindle server speaks HTTP/2.  However, on certain occasions, certain rare and vexatious occasions, when the Bindle server is hidden behind a proxy or tunnel, a low, brutish proxy or tunnel that clings to savage, degraded protocols such as HTTP/1.1.  The Bindle server is perfectly happy being talked via such a proxy or tunnel, but the _client_ cannot establish communication because the oafish, ignorant proxy fails to comprehend its initial HTTP/2 greeting.

For these cases, these sad cases, it is useful to be able to have the client approach the proxy using HTTP/1.1 (and request an upgrade to HTTP/2).  In my sample of 1 tunnelling service, this worked 100% of the time.  This PR adds an option to do exactly that.

For the time being, I have not surfaced this option on the Bindle CLI; it is only on the Bindle client crate.  However, we could make it available e.g. via an environment variable, or even default the CLI to this behaviour as the performance benefit of bypassing negotiation may not be significant in an interactive environment.

title: add a group_members function on invoice
body:
This adds a `group_members(name)` function on the invoice so that it is easy to get all of the parcels that belong to a group.

Ported over from Wagi.

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: fix(server): Respects RUST_LOG variable
body:
I found out that krustlet wasn't respecting it for the same reason, so
I added the change here as well

title: Update to newer Wasm/WASI directions
body: Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: Fixed deleted line in licence
body: Spotted while ~copying and pasting~ diligently reviewing my project's supply chain

title: fixed the help text for the search -q param
body:
This fixes the help text for the `bindle search`'s `-q` option.

Before, the text erroneously said that `-q ""` would return all results. Attempting this would result in an error. In practice, merely omitting the optional `-q` flag is sufficient to get all results.

It also erroneously stated that the query had to be the name of the bindle. In strict mode, the query must be part of the name. But in standard mode, the query could be applied to authors, description, version, and other fields as well.

Closes #124

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: fix strict query processing
body:
The previous implementation of search was stricter than the specification required. This relaxes strict processing.

The following should now work:

- an empty query
- an empty version filter
- a query whose term is a substring (e.g. `warp` should now match `enterprise.com/warpcore/1.0.0`)

Closes #98

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: add Accept-type negotiation for JSON and TOML
body:
Add content negotiation for JSON and TOML.

This adds support for using the `Accept` header to try to find the best format for sending results back. In addition, it accepts `invoice.json` content if the `content-type` is one of `text/json` or `application/json`.

Closes #132

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: log server-side warning when TOML fails to parse
body: Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: chore(*): Added tracing to client
body: Closes #129

title: chore(*): Switches to the `tracing` crate and instruments all server things
body:
This adds _a lot_ more tracing and instrumentation on most of the major functions
used for the server. It also adds in tracing to the warp processing pipeline, which
should help with debugging. The client code still needs to be updated with more logs
and with instrumentation, but I will do that in a follow up.

Please note that if you think the logs are too verbose or you don't like the format,
tracing is very very tweakable, so we can iterate on this and change it

title: Verify creator on invoice upload
body:
This PR wires up all of the signing and verification logic for the server.

Todo:

- [x] Unit test for VerificationStrategy

- [ ] ~~API server needs to be able to load strategy~~ Moved to #143

- [x] Attempt to remove Dalek from public API

title: update docs, add Makefile
body:
This updates the docs and adds a `Makefile` that hides away the growing complexity of our cargo commands.

Closes #125 

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: added a few about strings on commands that are confusing
body:
In the client, some commands say they take `BINDLE` for an argument, but don't specify what `BINDLE` is. I added a tiny bit of documentation.

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: ensure that a config directory exists before trying to use it
body:
Make sure that the config dir exists before attempting to use it.

Closes #116

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: fix label spec typo
body: A one-word fix

title: add sign-invoice command
body:
This is the third step toward implementing signing and verification. It uses a key created with `create-key` and signs an invoice.

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: Update simple-invoice.toml
body: Removes unneeded group from simple example

title: Add CLI command to create keyfile.
body:
Add support for creating and reading keyfiles. Adds `bindle create-key` command.

Closes #103

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: added a verify_label function to the key entry
body:
This is an addition to the Keyring code, adding a way to verify that the label on a key entry has not been tampered with.

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: add origin field to label for provenance
body:
This PR adds `origin` to `Label` and updates the spec to explain how to use it for tracking provenance.

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: added library support for yanked signature and keyring
body:
This brings the current signature library into parity with the current signing spec.

- Adds yanked_signature
- Adds keyring
- Adds key entry
- Adds key entry signing
- Fixes a snake_case typo in the spec

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: feat(server): Add optional config file
body:
Ref: #87

Default config file name is `server.toml` in the directory set by the
`dirs` crate.

  https://docs.rs/dirs/3.0.1/dirs/fn.config_dir.html

title: Fix versions in invoice spec sample
body: The version text in the sample in the invoice spec had gotten out of sync with modern thinking, and caused errors if you tried to serve the invoice from the spec.  This PR aligns the sample to the (presumably validated) test data.

title: updated to make yanking more secure
body: Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: Define the `approver` role
body:
This defines an `approver` role and goes into more detail about how verification works in Bindle.

Signed-off-by: Matt Butcher <matt.butcher@microsoft.com>

title: feat(server): Adds traits and noop types for authn/z
body: This also glues in the noop types into the bindle server routes, including some additional (and better) routing for parcels and bindles using warp filters

title: fix(*): Updates dependencies to latest patch
body:
Our current deps referenced a few yanked versions and it wasn't compiling
on my Mac when trying to publish. This is the lock file used to publish 0.3.1
